title: Unemployment rate in Belgium 2008 - 2018 , by region
summary: This is a multi-line chart with 3 lines representing Flemish Region, Brussels-Capital Region, and Walloon Region. The y axis denotes Employment rate and the x axis denotes Year.
Overall Brussels-Capital Region, and Walloon Region are gradually decreasing, Flemish Region is roughly constant,  throughout the Year
The ranking of the lines from topmost to botommmost is as follows: 1. Brussels-Capital Region, 2. Walloon Region, and lastly, 3. Flemish Region.
Throughout the period, Brussels-Capital Region generally had the highest Employment rate relative to others with an average of 16.77, and it reached its maximum at 2013 with a value of 19.3.
Followed by Walloon Region which ranks as the second topmpost line , with an average of 10.6 Employment rate,reaching its highest point  at 2015 with a value of 12.0.
The botommost line, Flemish Region,  has a mean of 4.65, and peaked at 2010, and 2015.
min_summary: The given chart is of multi-line type with 3 lines namely Flemish Region, Brussels-Capital Region, and Walloon Region. The y axis represents Employment rate and the x axis represents Year.
Overall Brussels-Capital Region, and Walloon Region are gradually decreasing, Flemish Region is roughly constant,  throughout the Year
Overall across the Year, Brussels-Capital Region mostly maintained the highest Employment rate when compared to others with a mean value of 16.77, and it peaked at 2013.
Followed by Walloon Region which ranks as the second topmpost line , with an average of 10.6 Employment rate,reaching its highest point  at 2015 with a value of 12.0.
The botommost line, Flemish Region,  has a mean of 4.65, and peaked at 2010, and 2015.

The ranking of the lines from topmost to botommmost is as follows: 1. Brussels-Capital Region, 2. Walloon Region, and lastly, 3. Flemish Region.

max_summary: The given chart is of multi-line type with 3 lines namely Flemish Region, Brussels-Capital Region, and Walloon Region. The y axis represents Employment rate and the x axis represents Year.
Overall Brussels-Capital Region, and Walloon Region are gradually decreasing, Flemish Region is roughly constant,  throughout the Year
The lines ordered according to average values of Employment rate in descending order is: 1. Brussels-Capital Region, 2. Walloon Region, and lastly, 3. Flemish Region.
Throughout the period, Brussels-Capital Region generally had the highest Employment rate relative to others with an average of 16.77, and it reached its maximum at 2013 with a value of 19.3.
Followed by Walloon Region which ranks as the second topmpost line , with an average of 10.6 Employment rate,reaching its highest point  at 2015 with a value of 12.0.
Flemish Region mostly had the least Employment rate with a mean value of 4.65, which peaked at 2010, and 2015 with a value of 5.2.
The minimum Employment rate about 3.5, occured at 2018 by Flemish Region.
